Message.Title: Kansas, Dallas, Richmond, Cleveland and Atlanta Fed Chiefs say scale back QE3
Message.Msg: Dallas Fed President Richard Fisher: The Fed should declare “victory” on housing, immediately begin tapering purchases of mortgage-backed securities and stop buying them by the end of the year, he said on May 16. Fisher also believes the Fed should taper purchases of Treasuries. *Kansas City Fed President Esther George: Fed policy is currently too easy, and the central bank should scale back bond-buying to reduce risks. George sees U.S. growth this year at 2 percent, and on April 4 repeated a warning that too much accommodation could lead to inflation. Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker: The Fed should stop buying mortgage-backed securities because the housing sector has recovered, and should reduce the pace of Treasury purchases. On May 3, he said there is no longer “any question” that the labor market outlook has improved substantially since the Fed began quantitative easing last September, and that markets “ought to evaluate the likelihood of us reducing the pace of asset purchases accordingly.” Cleveland Fed President Sandra Pianalto: The Fed could cut back on bond purchases to reduce the chance they could distort financial markets or encourage excessive risk taking; in addition, she said March 27, a large balance sheet could limit the Fed’s ability to respond to inflationary pressures. “Given our limited experience with our asset purchase programs, slowing the pace of purchases could help minimize the potential risks associated with our large and growing balance sheet,” she said on April 8. Message.Title: The Windows 8 Flop: What Does It Mean For Microsoft?
Message.Msg: Google it... Quoting: "Windows 8 was the revolution that wasn’t. But don’t count Microsoft MSFT +1.98% out just yet. In a lot of ways, the boring, button-down software giant was just a little ahead of its time. "After a storm of criticism from frustrated long-time Windows users, Microsoft announced that it would be making significant changes to its Windows 8 operating system. The details have not been released yet, but it’s assumed that they will include bringing back the “Start” button that has been a fixture in the lower-left corner since 1995 and giving desktop users the ability to bypass the tiled start screen on system startup. "Is this a failure for Microsoft? In some critical ways, yes. In a classic case of arrogance, Microsoft assumed that, after some initial grumbling, consumers would embrace the Windows 8 style because, frankly, they weren’t given a choice. "Few companies can get away with something like that. Arch-rival Apple AAPL +0.2% can, or at least could under the Steve Jobs regime. But Apple was a quirky exception in that its fans had an almost cult-like devotion to Jobs and would have likely drunk cyanide-laced Kool-Aid if he asked them to. Jobs could have gotten away with something as jolting as Windows 8. His replacement at Apple, Tim Cook, couldn’t get away it, and neither could Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer."

Message.Title: Inflation and gold
Message.Msg: I bought in 2001 at less than $300 an ounce and continued buying up to $800 an ounce, bought a handful of coins I wanted higher but basically bought as bullion. A $20 gold piece is still worth 70 times what it was worth 80 years ago, that's what printing does over time. Unless someone discovers a cheap way to get it from seawater it will be $10K an ounce at some point, paper is paper, gold costs $650/ounce to mine today the mining costs (in dollars) have more than doubled since 2001. For the market to truly hit new highs in adjusted dollars it would need to be 22,000+. Bernanke is playing a shell game and inflation will come when things improve a bit and F500 companies quit hoarding the money Bernanke is printing. There are no new rules, that's a fool's game.

Message.Title: Microsoft - Announcing Build June 26-28/2013
Message.Msg: Editor's Update: Build 2013 is now sold out; however, we encourage those interested in the conference to join the waitlist. For those who are unable to join us in San Francisco, we will extend the Build experience online with live streams of the keynote, sessions, Channel 9 Live and more. In the past year, we’ve introduced an assortment of new opportunities to build incredible apps and experiences on Windows, and developers all over the world have taken advantage of it. Just look at the last few weeks - we’ve seen great apps like Twitter on Windows 8 and Pandora on Windows Phone 8 as great examples of developers really taking advantage of the platform in a way that users love. But we're also seeing users increasingly expect their experiences on multiple screens, and Skulls of the Shogun is a great example of how Windows is the best place for developers to capitalize on the opportunity. And the opportunity is big: we saw more than 100 million downloads from the Windows Store in the first two months after GA, we crossed the 1 billion downloads mark in the Windows Phone Store, we saw a doubling of Windows Azure compute usage in just the last six months and much more. And developers are taking notice.

The V8 is punchy with its smooth eight-speed automatic, stately ride, and responsive handling, the V6 is a bargain luxury sedan and our preferred choice. In our tests it returned a good 22 mpg overall. Inside, the cabin is roomy and nicely trimmed. The Uconnect touch-screen infotainment system is one of the best in the industry. The SRT8, with a potent 6.4-liter V8 engine, is also available.
